channel.title: Comments on: Don’t prefix your table names with tbl
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Daniel Fountain
item.dc:creator: Daniel Fountain
item.content:encoded:
I disagree.

You say it does nothing to add to the clarity of the code. Ok…. heres some code.

Select * from Product

Now… find product in management studio. So you could look in tables, or views, or even functions.

So now i have

Select * from vwProduct

where you going to look? Views.

I agree it can be a pain to maintain and read – but to say it gives nothing to self documenting is not true.

item.title: By: Erik
item.dc:creator: Erik
item.content:encoded:
proI verBelieve proI auxHave advAdequately advPreviously vrbDemonstrated conWhy vrbUsing nouPrefixes vrbIs advReally adjLame.

proThis vrbIs artA adjGood nouExample prpOf advHow nouPrefixes vrbLook prpTo proMe–advSimply adjNasty.

That might help for a while if you’re really new to English, but it just trashes everything in the long run.

item.title: By: Christiaan Baes (chrissie1)
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Baes (chrissie1)
item.description: You want me to rename all my tables?
item.content:encoded: You want me to rename all my tables?

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.content:encoded:
I posted this yesterday as a comment in the other post but here it is again just for kicks

what about this table? Hungarion notation at its best ðŸ™‚

CREATE TABLE tblEmployee (
intID int identity not null,
strLastName varchar(255) not null,
strFirstName varchar(255) not null,
dtmBirthDate datetime null
mnyAnnualSalary money null
……
…..
….
